descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
This course is design to provide students with an opportunity to continue their pursuit of the classical ballet technique. It is a technique class with barre and center work. This class will have an emphasis on technical development, extended movement combinations and phrases, including the integration of a broader vocabulary (than the one given on Ballet I), adding more concepts of dynamics, attack, musicality, alignment, lines, use of space and artistry. This course will be challenging to the students both physically and intellectually.

Students must have taken ballet I prior to this course, and/or have had previous Ballet training

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
a) To broaden the students Classical Ballet Vocabulary
b) To increase center stability, strength, flexibility, coordination, confidence and clarity while executing the conbinations given
c) Improved body alignment
d) To have a better understanding on how to shift the weight from position to the next
e) To have a basic understanding of anatomy and kinesiology for injury prevention

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value:
a) participation -30%
b) Mid-term paper -20%
c) Final paper -20%
d) Final Evaluation -30%

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Students are required to have ballet slippers.
Women: Tights and leotard, Hair pulled back and out of the face
Men: Tights, dance belt and a fitted t-shirt

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Suggested)
descriptions.value:
1) Technical Manual and Dictionary of Classical Ballet by Gail Grant (third revised edition 1982)
2)Anatomy of movement by Blandine Calais-Germain (revised edition 1999)
3) Both sides of the mirror by Anna Paskevska. The science and Art of Ballet, (second edition 1992)
4) Ballet Beyond Tradition by Anna Paskevska 2004
